thread.title: Popovich pulls in LaMarcus Aldridge, and it’s a start
thread.title_full: Popovich pulls in LaMarcus Aldridge, and it’s a start - San Antonio Express-News

author: Buck Harvey
title: Popovich pulls in LaMarcus Aldridge, and it’s a start
text:
Photo: Edward A. Ornelas /San Antonio Express-News Image 1 of / 14 14 There’s no denying that Gregg Popovich will be judged on how he incorporates LaMarcus Aldridge (above) into the Spurs’ mix. There’s no denying that Gregg Popovich will be judged on how he incorporates LaMarcus Aldridge (above) into the Spurs’ mix. Photo: Edward A. Ornelas /San Antonio Express-News Image 2 of 14 Find out more about the Spurs' biggest free agent win. Find out more about the Spurs' biggest free agent win. Image 3 of 14 1. He's never been attention hungry
A previous Oregon Live article said Aldridge lack of attention was "common" for the star, it only fueled him. He told the website, "If I'm playing to get media and attention, I shouldn't be here [...] I'm here to play basketball and do what I can to help this team win." 1. He's never been attention hungry
A previous Oregon Live article said Aldridge lack of attention was "common" for the star, it only fueled him. He told the website, "If I'm playing to get media and attention, ... more Image 4 of 14 2. He's a leader
With his 220th double-double, he set the Portland Traiblazers' record, according to ESPN . 2. He's a leader
With his 220th double-double, he set the Portland Traiblazers' record, according to ESPN . Photo: Rocky Widner, Getty Images Image 5 of 14 3. He's another player who has had the opportunity to be on the court with his childhood hero, Tim Duncan
He called Duncan his favorite player growing up, partly because No. 21's body type looked more like his. Duncan reciprocated the admiration and said "he's a great young talent. It was the first time seeing him for me but he surprised me a little bit. They've got good talent over there," according to an NBA.c om interview. 3. He's another player who has had the opportunity to be on the court with his childhood hero, Tim Duncan
He called Duncan his favorite player growing up, partly because No. 21's body type looked more like his. ... more Image 6 of 14 4. His productivity is consistent
According to NBA.com , our newest Spur is just one of five players averaging 20-plus points in each of the past four seasons. He was also the Portland Trailblazer's second-leading scorer in their franchise's history. Let's see what he can do for the Spurs.
4. His productivity is consistent
According to NBA.com , our newest Spur is just one of five players averaging 20-plus points in each of the past four seasons. He was also the Portland Trailblazer's ... more Image 7 of 14 5. During his rookie years, he called dunking over Duncan "the highlight" of his professional career
In a Q&A session , Aldridge called his future teammate the "toughest guy to guard" and added, "he is so smart and knows where to go and how to get in position to score. To get one down on a player of his caliber is a great accomplishment." 5. During his rookie years, he called dunking over Duncan "the highlight" of his professional career
In a Q&A session , Aldridge called his future teammate the "toughest guy to guard" and added, "he is so smart ... more Image 8 of 14 6. He's following iconic footsteps
In 2013, Aldridge was named NBA Western Conference Player of the Week for the fourth time (he's held the title eight times,) by tallying 30 points, 21 rebounds, three assists and three steals. The only other player to accomplish an identical set of stats was David Robinson, according to NBA.com . 6. He's following iconic footsteps
In 2013, Aldridge was named NBA Western Conference Player of the Week for the fourth time (he's held the title eight times,) by tallying 30 points, 21 rebounds, three assists ... more Image 9 of 14 7. In 2007, he was diagnosed with a heart condition
Aldridge suffered from Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome (WPW), which is a problem with the heart's electrical system causing it to be abnormally. He underwent surgery at the time of his diagnosis and again in 2011 to treat the problem. 7. In 2007, he was diagnosed with a heart condition
Aldridge suffered from Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome (WPW), which is a problem with the heart's electrical system causing it to be abnormally. He underwent ... more Image 10 of 14 8. He was 6-foot-7 in middle school
But even then he was overlooked. He once said in an NBA.com interview, "I couldn't shoot. I couldn't do a hook shot. I was just tall and only scored points because everyone else was shorter than me," but his big brother, LaVontae, helped right him on his athletic path. 8. He was 6-foot-7 in middle school
But even then he was overlooked. He once said in an NBA.com interview, "I couldn't shoot. I couldn't do a hook shot. I was just tall and only scored points because everyone ... more Image 11 of 14 9. He's had four NBA All-Star appearances
From 2012 to 2015, he's competed with the best in the league. 9. He's had four NBA All-Star appearances
From 2012 to 2015, he's competed with the best in the league. Photo: ChinaFotoPress, Getty Images Image 12 of 14 10. He's a self-proclaimed "mama's boy"
He dished about his No. 1 lady in this Instagram post and in an NBA.com interview. "When I was younger, I used to spend a lot of time either by myself or with my mom," he said. "But when I hit high school, she really became on of my close friends." Looks like he has something in common with Kawhi Leonard. 10. He's a self-proclaimed "mama's boy"
He dished about his No. 1 lady in this Instagram post and in an NBA.com interview. "When I was younger, I used to spend a lot of time either by myself or with my mom," ... more Image 13 of 14 11. His hands do more than sink clutch shots
He has also been known to tickle the ivory from time to time. 11. His hands do more than sink clutch shots
He has also been known to tickle the ivory from time to time. Photo: 2010 AFP Image 14 of 14 Popovich pulls in LaMarcus Aldridge, and it’s a start 1 / 14 Back to Gallery The names over the lockers in the AT&T Center seem to be in no particular order. They stretch along three walls without concern for seniority or friendship or the alphabet.
But, as it often is with Gregg Popovich , nothing happens by accident.
One Spur dresses next to another Spur because Popovich thinks they should, and some motives are basic. Avoiding cliques would be one.
Other reasons are personal. Tim Duncan continues to locker in the same corner where he’s been for a dozen years, even after the arena redesign, because he’s always been there and he likes it there.
But Popovich also weighs the dynamic of how one personality affects another. There’s no telling how he evaluated all the variables, or why he assigned this particular spot, so his reason for his placement of LaMarcus Aldridge is unclear.
It’s this: Center, prominent, between Tony Parker and Patty Mills .
Maybe Popovich wanted Aldridge in the middle of everything. Maybe he wanted him between his point guards.
Maybe he wanted the outgoing and upbeat Mills, who played with Aldridge in Portland, close by. Or maybe, too, he wanted two non-American accents to remind Aldridge this locker room is unlike any other.
But whatever the thinking, this seemingly small decision is just part of a project that is both intriguing and essential to the success of the Spurs.
Even in May and June, after all, Popovich will still be judged on how he incorporates Aldridge.
Popovich comes across to his staff as ready for this. He’s fitter than he was at this time last year, and better health has translated to a more positive approach. They say he’s easier to talk to.
Winning the summer helped Popovich’s outlook, but winning the spring will be something else entirely. Signing Aldridge doesn’t guarantee the Spurs a championship, but it gives the Spurs two things.
A chance — and an extension of their relevancy.
The latter should not be overlooked. LaMarcus Nurae Aldridge, for example, was born in July of 1985. Just two years later, when he was running around as a toddler, the Spurs were winning the David Robinson lottery and beginning a run that still hasn’t ended.
Aldridge, growing up in North Texas, said he didn’t notice. He didn’t pick up a basketball until he was in the fourth grade, and he didn’t follow the sport.
He was aware of Michael Jordan , but only because everyone was. If Aldridge grew to be a fan of any sports team, it was the Dallas Cowboys .
Basketball came to him late. And all the time he was growing, and he was discovering his remarkable gifts, the Spurs kept winning.
Other franchises have won more championships. But none have had this kind of consistent success, over the span of four decades, which is where Aldridge already fits in. His arrival promises to continue that.
The Spurs’ history affected Aldridge’s decision last summer. He always idolized Duncan, and he saw firsthand in the 2014 playoffs how Popovich’s system could impact a series.
Still, there have been times when Aldridge sounds as if he isn’t sure why he chose the Spurs. He says he’s never been a person comfortable with change.
His second choice fit more with what Aldridge had been in Portland. The Phoenix Suns would have been contenders with him, but Aldridge would have been the star again, separated by his talent. That’s a reason he became a loner in Portland, often isolated from those he lockered next to.
In choosing the Spurs, Aldridge submitted to something else entirely. For those who are open to amateur psychology, perhaps this is what happened: Aldridge understood he needed to change and go against his nature.
Enter Popovich, ever trying to figure out the complex maze of human emotions. If he’s excited about drawing up X’s and O’s for Aldridge, he’s obsessed working toward the larger goal — assimilating Aldridge into his mix.
Popovich already had a few things on his side, namely Duncan, Manu Ginobili and a culture of winning. The Spurs have long known how to get along, and a moment this fall on the road showed that.
Others have wondered if Aldridge would ever follow Popovich’s let’s-eat-as-a-team lead. But there was Boris Diaw after a preseason game in Miami, going around the locker room, seeing who wanted to go out for dinner together.
Without hesitation, Aldridge said yes.
Popovich was given another tool with an annual preseason activity. When H-E-B asked to include Aldridge in its commercials, it was a natural way for Aldridge to hang with Duncan, Ginobili and Mills and feel like one of the guys.
Popovich has found ways in practice, too. He has consistently paired Duncan with Aldridge, keeping them together as a unit, when Popovich usually likes to mix and match.
Assistants have noticed and aren’t sure why. Maybe it’s to create familiarity. Or maybe it’s a way for Popovich to announce Aldridge’s status, to tell Aldridge, too, he and Duncan are in this together.
As it is with the assigned locker stalls, the reasoning is uncertain but the message is consistent. Popovich is pulling in Aldridge, getting him to invest in the group — because that’s how the Spurs have won before.
bharvey@express-news.net
Twitter: Buck_SA
